10.41.text:
JASON SILVA: So I'm really
fascinated by the way

15.98.text:
Where set and setting meet
awareness and consciousness.

21.51.text: So why do people like sunrises?

25.46.text:
And I think it's because it's a
moment in which we can actually

28.23.text:
witness the transformation--
the transition from day

31.77.text: to night, or from night to day.

34.32.text:
In ordinary waking states, we
cannot perceive the passing

38.41.text:
And so this perception--
this increased juxtaposition

42.28.text:
of day and night-- forces
us to be more present.

45.65.text:
It forces an experience
of time, dilation,

48.98.text:
that transforms how we
perceive the moment.

52.04.text:
The moment becomes impregnated
with a sense of importance,

57.36.text:
The sunset context
essentially frames the moment

61.41.text:
and induces, hopefully, a
transformative experience.

65.81.text:
And thus we are left
with that feeling of,

67.76.text:
oh, that was really meaningful,
or oh, that was really special.

71.34.text:
We crave these moments, and we
work hard for these moments,

73.98.text:
and we strive to
author these moments.

76.07.text:
But a lot of times, they are
right there for the taking.

78.95.text:
If only we were aware enough
to open our eyes and plug in.
